title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Nearly opposite, upon the right, is Kennet House, the seat of Eobert Bruce, Esq. of Kennet.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Near the town, inthe vale of Kennet, is a vast peat mossy extending 16 miles in length, with nearly amile in breadth, and from which greatquantities of peats are dug.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Newarkwas long famous for its extensive manufactures ; and the famous John Winchcombe,known by the name of Jack of Newbury,who built part of the church, is said to haveemployed upwards of 100 looms in the manufacture of broad cloth ; this trade, however, has greatly declined ; scarcely anykind of cloth is now made, except serges,shalloons, and trus3els ; and the Chief tradeof the town consists in malting, and in thetraffic carried on upon the Kennet and Avoncanal, which joins the Thames with the Severn, and opens a communication fromReading, by Newbury, to Bath and Bris-itol.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Thetown-hall is a handsome building, erectedover the market-place, near the bridgewhich crosses the Kennet.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: It is situatedin a fertile plain, on the banks of the Kennet, which runs through the centre of thetown.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Maulborough, a market town of England, in the county of Wilts, situated onthe river Kennet, and on the great roadfrom London to Bath and Bristol.

title: Travels in lands beyond the sea.
author: Linskill, Charles Dorrance.
snippet: We pass through East Grange, Bogside, Kincardine  and Kennet, Clark-Manning, Alloa Junction and Cambus.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: In his way, however, he encountered Adam, who, without wasting a word upon the matter, took him up in one hand and flung him into the Kennet.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: It was Spring in all its loveliness, and never is Spring more lovely than in our Kennet meadows.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: The next time that I passed by the banks of the Kennet was in the lovely season which just precedes the merry month of May.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: His habitation was, as I have said, beautifully  situated at a point of the Kennet where, winding suddenly round an abrupt hill, it flowed beneath a bank so high and precipitous, that but for its verdure it might have passed for a cliff, leaving just room on the bank for a small white cottage, the chimneys of which were greatly over-topped by the woody ridge behind them, while the garden on one side sloped in natural terraces from the hill to the river, and a narrow orchard on the other was planted ledge above ledge, like a vineyard on the Rhine.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Gilbert, who in right of his terrene avocations  wears a green livery and a gold-laced hat, is by no means a regular inhabitant of the cottage by the Kennet side, but may be found quite as frequently up at the park, sometimes at the dog-kennel, sometimes in the servants' hall, leaving the river to the efficient watchfulness of its amphibious guardians,  Adam Stokes, the boy Ned, and their dog Neptune, who, excepting when Adam was attracted by the charms of a stronger liquid to the tap-room of the Four Horseshoes, were seldom seen half a furlong from their proper element.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Our business, however, is not with the mighty Thames the " wealthiest of rivers " but with the pleasant and pastoral Kennet.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Next we have the Kennet " the Kennet swift, for silver eels renowned," according to the same author, and which, in our part at least, has, generally speaking, a fine pastoral character, now sweeping along through broad valleys of meadow-land, rich and green, and finely dappled by trees, chiefly oak and elm, in park-like groups ; now confined within a narrower channel, and spanned by some lofty bridge as it passes the quiet village or small country-town, enlivening every scene which it approaches by the pleasant slow of its clear

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The wind which had been sovery serviceable to us from Kennet Pans, was now inour teeth, and we had to begin beating to get intothe Downs.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: She turned out to be the vessel towed down theForth from Alloa the night before we started fromKennet Pans.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The steam tug ' Yorkshire Lass,'from Alloa, brought down from that town a schoonerto Kennet to load coal, and then took us in tow forLeith Roads.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: At half-past six in the morning of Friday, August24, we started from Kennet Pans, laden with 260 tonsof coal, as I have already stated, for St. Valery-en-Caux, in France.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: At length an offer was made to him, which heaccepted, to take a cargo of coal from Kennet Pans,a small port up the Forth, to St. Valery-en-Caux, inFrance, and to bring back to Runcorn a cargo offlints, &c. This he accepted, and now he began tolook after his ballast.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: We were chartered from Kennet Pans, up the Firthof Forth, with a load of coals for St. Valery-en-Caux,in France, and again from St. Valery-en-Caux to Runcorn with a load of flints to be used in the manufacture of china and earthenware.
